case_title: MUHAMMAD AKBAR JAFFAR vs GOVERNMENT OF BALUCHISTAN

charges.description: Accumulated huge amount of money by accepting illegal gratifications for issuing permits of second-hand clothing, onions, and potatoes.
Assumed a style of living beyond his means and purchased a house worth Rs. 5 lacs in the name of his mother-in-law, disproportionate to his known sources of income.
Associated and mixed up with notorious smugglers and helped them in their smuggling operations.

key_issues.issue: Violation of mandatory provisions of Efficiency and Discipline Rules, 1974.
key_issues.finding: Rules 5 and 6 were infringed during the inquiry process.
Inquiry Officer was found to have acted with bias and overstepped his jurisdiction.
Charges were based on presumptions and conjectures, not on direct evidence.
House belonged to the appellant's mother-in-law, and no evidence proved appellant's ownership.

tribunal_decision.majority_opinion: Appeal allowed due to procedural defects and lack of evidence.
tribunal_decision.minority_opinion: Appeal dismissed, appellant found guilty of charges.

order.instructions: Appellant reinstated in service from 30th March, 1977. Authority may conduct a fresh inquiry through an impartial Inquiry Officer if deemed necessary.
